holdings.text: hold that the deity was the grantee and the first question raised before us must be answered against the appellants

anchor.surface_text: it will be noticed that neither in the Inam Register Ex. P/3 nor in the statement Ex. D/3 is there any mention of the Archakas as the grantee or for the matter of that, having any the least -interest, personal or otherwise, in the subject-matter of the Inam grant. The two exhibits quite clearly indicate that the Inam grant was made in favour of the temple by the grantor and that in the face of this definite evidence and proof of the nature of the grant, no presumption of a lost grant can be made in favour of the Archakas. We, therefore, in agreement with the High Court, hold that the deity was the grantee and the first question raised before us must be answered against the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inam Register Ex. P/3 and statement Ex. D/3 name temple as grantee and enjoyer with no mention of Archakas having any interest; this provides convincing proof rebutting lost grant presumption

holdings.text: no presumption of a lost grant can be made in favour of the Archakas

anchor.surface_text: The two exhibits quite clearly indicate that the Inam grant was made in favour of the temple by the grantor and that in the face of this definite evidence and proof of the nature of the grant, no presumption of a lost grant can be made in favour of the Archakas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sufficient and convincing evidence from official Inam Register and contemporary statement proves grant nature and grantee, precluding presumption

holdings.text: this Inam grant in favour of the temple comprised both the interests in the land

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the different entries under the different columns in Exhibit P/3 and Exhibit D/3 there is no escape from the position that this Inam grant in favour of the temple comprised both the interests in the land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different entries in Inam documents under various columns show full grant of both melvaram and kudivaram; prior case distinguished on facts (Archakas not grantees there, equal amounts); flawed reasoning rejected as register entries identical regardless of grant extent

holdings.text: those considerations appear to us to be entirely out of place in a suit for ejectment on proof of title

anchor.surface_text: but those considerations appear to us to be entirely out of place in a suit for ejectment on proof of title. If the two decisions lay down, as it is contended they do, that the principles which may have a bearing on a proceeding for framing of a scheme or for enforcing the scheme that is framed may be applied to a case of the kind we have before us it will be difficult for us to uphold them either on authority or on principle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity and moral claims for Archakas relevant only in temple scheme framing proceedings, not in possessory suit based on title proof; Archakas' adverse claim despite predecessors' admission disentitles equity

holdings.text: In a proceeding for the framing of a scheme relating to a temple it may be permissible to take into account the claims, moral if not legal, of the Archakas and to make some provision for protecting their rights

anchor.surface_text: In a proceeding for the framing of a scheme relating to a temple it may be permissible to take into account the claims, moral if not legal, of the Archakas and to make some provision for protecting their rights, but those considerations appear to us to be entirely out of place in a suit for ejectment on proof of title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between scheme framing (where moral claims may be considered) and title ejectment suits
